definition: Provincial social assistance programs administered by the City (e.g., Ontario Works and related benefits).
details: Who: City divisions and community partners. What/How: operating costs to deliver social supports, housing, health, or child care services, including staffing, benefits, and program delivery. Why/Where: supports residents across Toronto and is reported in the FIR for the fiscal year. Legal basis: Ontario Works Act, 1997.

definition: Programs that support seniors, including housing and income support services.
details: Who: City divisions and community partners. What/How: operating costs to deliver social supports, housing, health, or child care services, including staffing, benefits, and program delivery. Why/Where: supports residents across Toronto and is reported in the FIR for the fiscal year.

definition: Municipal taxes set by the City, primarily property taxes and related levies.
details: Who: City of Toronto. What/How: property taxes and related municipal levies set by Council and applied to assessed values within Toronto. Why: primary source of municipal operating revenue.

definition: Provincial transfers earmarked for specific programs or services.
details: Who: provincial, federal, or municipal partners. What/How: targeted transfers restricted to eligible programs or capital projects with reporting conditions. Why: funds shared priorities or infrastructure; recognized in the FIR when conditions are met.

definition: Federal transfers earmarked for specific programs or services.
details: Who: provincial, federal, or municipal partners. What/How: targeted transfers restricted to eligible programs or capital projects with reporting conditions. Why: funds shared priorities or infrastructure; recognized in the FIR when conditions are met.

definition: Revenue previously received but recognized when conditions are met (e.g., development charges).
details: Who: City finance reporting. What/How: revenue previously received but deferred until eligibility conditions are met (e.g., development charges or restricted grants). Why: aligns revenue recognition with public-sector accounting rules.

definition: City tax on real estate transactions within Toronto.
details: Who: City of Toronto. What/How: tax on the transfer of land or real estate in Toronto, payable on closing through the land registration process; rates set by the Municipal Code. Why: raises municipal revenue alongside the provincial land transfer tax. Legal basis: Toronto Municipal Code Chapter 760.

definition: Interest and returns on City reserves and investments.
details: Who: City treasury. What/How: interest and investment returns on City cash, reserves, and reserve funds. Why: generates revenue while funds are held for future use.

definition: Revenue from leases, concessions, and franchise agreements.
details: Who: City of Toronto and its tenants or concessionaires. What/How: revenue from leasing City assets, concessions, or franchise agreements. Why: monetizes City-owned assets and rights.

definition: Non-cash infrastructure or assets contributed to the City.
details: Who: developers, partners, or other contributors. What/How: non-cash capital assets contributed to the City (e.g., developer-built infrastructure) recorded at fair value. Why: recognizes in-kind infrastructure added to the City's asset base.

definition: Tax on residential properties left vacant.
details: Who: City of Toronto. What/How: tax on residential properties declared or deemed vacant for most of the year; owners must file annual occupancy declarations and may qualify for exemptions. Why: encourages housing availability and raises revenue; applied within Toronto under Municipal Code Chapter 778.

definition: City share of revenues from gaming and casino operations.
details: Who: City of Toronto, under municipal bylaws or provincial/federal authority. What/How: revenue collected from the relevant tax base, fees, or enforcement activity within Toronto. Why: funds municipal services and is reported in the FIR for the fiscal year.

term: Revenue From Other Municipalities for Tangible Capital Assets
definition: Transfers from other municipalities for shared capital assets or joint projects.
details: Who: other municipalities. What/How: transfers or cost-sharing for jointly funded capital assets or shared infrastructure projects. Why: recognizes partner funding for capital works.
matches: revenue from other municipalities for tangible capital assets

definition: Federal transfer (formerly Gas Tax) for infrastructure and community investments.
details: Who: Government of Canada. What/How: federal transfer (formerly the Gas Tax Fund) allocated by formula for municipal infrastructure and community investments. Why: funds eligible capital projects and is recognized when conditions are met.

term: Canada Grants for Tangible Capital Assets
definition: Federal grants for capital assets and infrastructure projects.
details: Who: provincial, federal, or municipal partners. What/How: targeted transfers restricted to eligible programs or capital projects with reporting conditions. Why: funds shared priorities or infrastructure; recognized in the FIR when conditions are met.
matches: canada grants for tangible capital assets

term: Ontario Grants for Tangible Capital Assets
definition: Provincial grants for capital assets and infrastructure projects.
details: Who: provincial, federal, or municipal partners. What/How: targeted transfers restricted to eligible programs or capital projects with reporting conditions. Why: funds shared priorities or infrastructure; recognized in the FIR when conditions are met.
matches: ontario grants for tangible capital assets

definition: Funding from organizations not included in the City's consolidated financial statements.
details: Who: organizations not included in the City's consolidated financial statements. What/How: funding contributions or cost-sharing for City services or projects. Why: recognizes external funding in the City's results.

term: Gain (Loss) on Sale of Land & Capital Assets
definition: Net gains or losses from selling land or capital assets.
details: Who: City finance reporting. What/How: difference between sale proceeds and the book value of land or capital assets. Why: records the financial impact of asset disposals in the City's statements.
matches: gain (loss) on sale of land & capital assets

term: Interest Earned on Reserves and Reserve Funds
definition: Interest earned on City reserves and reserve funds.
details: Who: City treasury. What/How: interest earned on reserve and reserve fund balances held for specific purposes. Why: grows reserves and is reported as investment income.
matches: interest earned on reserves and reserve funds

definition: Fees collected for licenses, permits, and approvals.
details: Who: City of Toronto. What/How: fees for licenses, permits, and approvals required for business, construction, or activities. Why: funds regulation, inspections, and administrative costs.

definition: Fines that do not fit into other specified categories.
details: Who: City of Toronto. What/How: fines from bylaw or regulatory enforcement not captured in other categories. Why: supports compliance and enforcement activities.

term: Other Revenues from Government Business Enterprise
definition: Earnings from City-owned business enterprises beyond regular dividends.
details: Who: City-owned business enterprises. What/How: earnings or dividends from municipal enterprises beyond regular dividend payments. Why: records enterprise income in City revenue.
matches: other revenues from government business enterprise

definition: Payments from tax-exempt properties in lieu of property taxes.
details: Who: federal/provincial governments and other tax-exempt property owners. What/How: payments made instead of property taxes for eligible properties under separate legislation. Why: compensates municipalities for services provided to tax-exempt properties. Legal basis: Payments in Lieu of Taxes Act (Canada).

sources.type: Payments in Lieu of Taxes Act (Canada)

definition: Late fees, penalties, and interest charged on tax balances.
details: Who: City of Toronto. What/How: late fees, penalties, and interest charged on overdue tax balances. Why: encourages timely payment and recovers financing costs.

definition: Provincial gas tax transfers used for transit or infrastructure.
details: Who: Government of Ontario. What/How: provincial transfer dedicated to public transit, allocated to municipalities by formula. Why: supports transit systems and is recognized when eligibility conditions are met.

term: Provincial Gas Tax for Transit Capital Expenses
definition: Gas tax transfers used for transit capital projects.
details: Who: Government of Ontario. What/How: portion of gas tax transfer used for transit capital projects such as vehicles, stations, and infrastructure. Why: funds long-lived transit assets.
matches: provincial gas tax for transit capital expenses

term: Provincial Gas Tax for Transit Operating Expenses
definition: Gas tax transfers used for transit operating costs.
details: Who: Government of Ontario. What/How: portion of gas tax transfer used for transit operating costs such as service delivery, maintenance, and operations. Why: supports day-to-day transit service.
matches: provincial gas tax for transit operating expenses

definition: Administration of provincial offences (e.g., traffic tickets), including courts, enforcement, and related fees.
details: Who: City of Toronto under the Provincial Offences Act. What/How: revenue from administering provincial offences such as traffic tickets, including fines, court fees, and recoveries. Why: supports enforcement and court administration in Toronto. Legal basis: Provincial Offences Act (Ontario).
matches: provincial offences act (poa) municipality which administers poa only

definition: Transfers or recoveries from other municipalities.
details: Who: other municipalities. What/How: transfers or recoveries for shared services or agreements. Why: reflects cost-sharing for cross-jurisdiction services.

definition: Revenue from selling publications, equipment, or materials.
details: Who: City of Toronto. What/How: revenue from selling publications, materials, or surplus equipment. Why: recovers costs and generates minor revenues from sales.

definition: Hotel tax collected on short-term accommodations.
details: Who: City of Toronto. What/How: tax on short-term accommodations collected by operators and remitted to the City under the Municipal Accommodation Tax program. Why: supports tourism-related and municipal services. Legal basis: Toronto Municipal Code Chapter 758.

definition: Emergency call intake and dispatch for paramedic services.
details: Who: City public safety services and partners. What/How: operating costs for emergency response, enforcement, and protective services, including staffing, equipment, and facilities. Why/Where: protects residents and property across Toronto and is reported in the FIR.

definition: Paramedic operations and emergency medical response.
details: Who: City public safety services and partners. What/How: operating costs for emergency response, enforcement, and protective services, including staffing, equipment, and facilities. Why/Where: protects residents and property across Toronto and is reported in the FIR.

definition: Building permits, inspections, and code enforcement.
details: Who: Council, corporate leadership, and shared service divisions. What/How: governance and administrative support that enables service delivery, including policy, finance, HR, IT, and regulatory functions. Why: ensures citywide coordination and compliance; reported in the FIR under general government.

term: Child Care and Early Years Learning
definition: Child care services and early learning programs.
details: Who: City divisions and community partners. What/How: operating costs to deliver social supports, housing, health, or child care services, including staffing, benefits, and program delivery. Why/Where: supports residents across Toronto and is reported in the FIR for the fiscal year.
matches: child care and early years learning

definition: Services related to commercial and industrial activity.
details: Who: Council, corporate leadership, and shared service divisions. What/How: governance and administrative support that enables service delivery, including policy, finance, HR, IT, and regulatory functions. Why: ensures citywide coordination and compliance; reported in the FIR under general government.

definition: Funding for conservation authority programs and watershed management.
details: Who: City utility and environment services. What/How: operating costs for water, wastewater, stormwater, solid waste, and related programs. Why: maintains essential infrastructure and compliance; reported in the FIR.

definition: City-wide management and corporate administration.
details: Who: Council, corporate leadership, and shared service divisions. What/How: governance and administrative support that enables service delivery, including policy, finance, HR, IT, and regulatory functions. Why: ensures citywide coordination and compliance; reported in the FIR under general government.

definition: Security for courts and judicial facilities.
details: Who: City public safety services and partners. What/How: operating costs for emergency response, enforcement, and protective services, including staffing, equipment, and facilities. Why/Where: protects residents and property across Toronto and is reported in the FIR.

definition: Arts and cultural programs and services.
details: Who: City divisions and cultural partners. What/How: operating costs for cultural and recreation services, including facilities, programs, and maintenance. Why: provides community amenities across Toronto; reported in the FIR.

definition: Emergency management and preparedness.

details: Who: Council, corporate leadership, and shared service divisions. What/How: governance and administrative support that enables service delivery, including policy, finance, HR, IT, and regulatory functions. details: Who: City divisions and cultural partners. What/How: operating costs for cultural and recreation services, including facilities, programs, and maintenance. Why: provides community amenities across Toronto; reported in the FIR.

details: Who: City transportation services. What/How: operating and maintenance costs for roads, transit, traffic operations, parking, and winter control. Why: keeps transportation networks safe and functional; reported in the FIR.

details: Who: City divisions and cultural partners. What/How: operating costs for cultural and recreation services, including facilities, programs, and maintenance. Why: provides community amenities across Toronto; reported in the FIR.

details: Who: Council, corporate leadership, and shared service divisions. details: Who: City public safety services and partners. What/How: operating costs for emergency response, enforcement, and protective services, including staffing, equipment, and facilities. Why/Where: protects residents and property across Toronto and is reported in the FIR.

details: Who: City public safety services and partners. What/How: operating costs for emergency response, enforcement, and protective services, including staffing, equipment, and facilities. Why/Where: protects residents and property across Toronto and is reported in the FIR.

details: Who: Council, corporate leadership, and shared service divisions. What/How: governance and administrative support that enables service delivery, including policy, finance, HR, IT, and regulatory functions. Why: ensures citywide coordination and compliance; reported in the FIR under general government.

definition: Inspection and enforcement for public safety and compliance.
details: Who: City public safety services and partners. What/How: operating costs for emergency response, enforcement, and protective services, including staffing, equipment, and facilities. Why/Where: protects residents and property across Toronto and is reported in the FIR.

definition: Public health programs and services.
details: Who: City divisions and community partners. What/How: operating costs to deliver social supports, housing, health, or child care services, including staffing, benefits, and program delivery. Why/Where: supports residents across Toronto and is reported in the FIR for the fiscal year.

definition: Public housing operations and supports.
details: Who: City divisions and community partners. What/How: operating costs to deliver social supports, housing, health, or child care services, including staffing, benefits, and program delivery. Why/Where: supports residents across Toronto and is reported in the FIR for the fiscal year.

definition: Operations for recreation facilities not listed elsewhere.
details: Who: City divisions and cultural partners. What/How: operating costs for cultural and recreation services, including facilities, programs, and maintenance. Why: provides community amenities across Toronto; reported in the FIR.

definition: Operations for city golf courses, marinas, and ski hill.
details: Who: City divisions and cultural partners. What/How: operating costs for cultural and recreation services, including facilities, programs, and maintenance. Why: provides community amenities across Toronto; reported in the FIR.

definition: Traffic operations, signals, and roadside services.

details: Who: City utility and environment services. What/How: operating costs for water, wastewater, stormwater, solid waste, and related programs. Why: maintains essential infrastructure and compliance; reported in the FIR.

definition: Conventional public transit operations.

definition: Storm sewer system operations and maintenance.
details: Who: City utility and environment services. What/How: operating costs for water, wastewater, stormwater, solid waste, and related programs. Why: maintains essential infrastructure and compliance; reported in the FIR.

details: Who: City utility and environment services. What/How: operating costs for water, wastewater, stormwater, solid waste, and related programs. Why: maintains essential infrastructure and compliance; reported in the FIR.

term: Winter Control - Except Sidewalks, Parking Lots
definition: Road winter maintenance such as plowing and salting.
details: Who: City transportation services. What/How: operating and maintenance costs for roads, transit, traffic operations, parking, and winter control. Why: keeps transportation networks safe and functional; reported in the FIR.
matches: winter control - except sidewalks, parking lots

term: Winter Control - Sidewalks, Parking Lots Only
definition: Winter maintenance for sidewalks and parking lots.
details: Who: City transportation services. What/How: operating and maintenance costs for roads, transit, traffic operations, parking, and winter control. Why: keeps transportation networks safe and functional; reported in the FIR.
matches: winter control - sidewalks, parking lots only

definition: Miscellaneous items not classified elsewhere. In the flow view, "Other" also groups any line items that do not match a bucket rule.
details: Catch-all line item for items not classified elsewhere in the FIR. In the flow view, this also aggregates items that do not match a bucket rule.

definition: A vote to accept a recommendation or item exactly as written. This is the final decision on whether something becomes policy.
details: Who: City Council or Committee. What/How: The council votes yes or no on accepting a recommendation in its original form. Why: This is the definitive vote that determines if a motion passes or fails. If adopted, the item becomes official city policy or direction.

definition: A vote to accept a recommendation AFTER it has been modified by amendments. The final version differs from what was originally proposed.
details: Who: City Council or Committee. What/How: After one or more amendments pass, this vote adopts the modified version of the item. Why: Indicates the original proposal was changed before passing. The amendments that passed are incorporated into the final decision.

definition: A proposal to change the wording, scope, or substance of an item before it's adopted. Shows someone wanted to modify the original proposal.
details: Who: Any councillor. What/How: A councillor proposes specific changes to the item text, funding amounts, conditions, or scope. Council then votes on whether to accept the amendment. Why: Amendments allow council to modify proposals rather than simply accepting or rejecting them. High amendment activity indicates negotiation and debate.

definition: A subsequent amendment after one has already been proposed. Indicates active negotiation or debate about the specifics of an item.
details: Who: Any councillor. What/How: After an initial amendment is proposed, additional councillors can propose further changes. Multiple amendments are voted on separately. Why: Multiple amendments signal a contentious item where different councillors want different modifications.

definition: Postpone the vote to a future meeting. Often used strategically to buy time, build coalitions, gather more information, or time decisions politically.
details: Who: Any councillor. What/How: A motion to delay consideration of the item to a specified future date or indefinitely. Requires a vote. Why: Deferral can signal opposition (buying time to organize), uncertainty (need more information), or political timing (wait for better circumstances). Items can be deferred multiple times.

definition: Send the item back to a committee or staff for more work or study. Signals the item isn't ready or needs revision.
details: Who: Any councillor. What/How: A motion to send the item to a standing committee or city staff for further review, consultation, or revision. The item may return with a new recommendation. Why: Referral is softer than voting Noit acknowledges the issue but requests more work. Can be used strategically to delay contentious items.

definition: Reopen a decision that was already made earlier in the same meeting. Rare and significantmeans someone changed their mind or new information emerged.
details: Who: A councillor who voted with the majority. What/How: A motion to undo or redo a previous vote from the same meeting. Usually requires the mover to have been on the winning side of the original vote. Why: Very unusual and signals controversy or a significant development. May indicate lobbying during breaks or new information coming to light.

definition: Similar to reconsider, but for items from previous meetings. Requires a two-thirds majority. A major procedural move.
details: Who: Any councillor. What/How: A motion to bring back an item that was decided at a previous meeting for a new vote. Requires 2/3 majority to pass. Why: Very significantindicates serious concerns about a previous decision. Rare because of the high threshold required.

definition: Cut off discussion and move to vote immediately. Used when debate is dragging on. Can be controversial if used to silence opposition.
details: Who: Any councillor. What/How: A procedural motion to stop all remaining speakers and proceed directly to the vote. Requires a vote to pass. Why: Can be legitimate (debate exhausted, time constraints) or controversial (preventing opposition from being heard). Watch for patterns of who calls this motion.

definition: Council meetings have scheduled end times. This vote extends past that time. Late-night votes often happen on contentious items.
details: Who: Any councillor. What/How: When the scheduled meeting end time approaches, council votes on whether to continue. Requires a vote. Why: Important but not urgent items may be pushed to late hours. Late-night votes can favor those with more stamina or fewer commitments.

definition: Skip the normal referral to committee and vote directly. Used for urgent matters or when something is straightforward.
details: Who: Any councillor. What/How: Bypasses the normal committee review process to allow direct council action. Requires a vote. Why: Urgent items may need fast action. However, skipping committee review means less scrutiny and public input.

definition: Accept a report without taking action. Just acknowledging receipt. Low stakesno policy change.
details: Who: City Council or Committee. What/How: The council officially receives a report or update but takes no action on it. Why: Informational items keep council informed without requiring decisions. Voting No on receive-for-information is very rare and signals objection to even acknowledging the report.
